title: Right Conductive Hearing Loss with Otalgia and Perforation
chief_complaint: I have had decreased hearing in my right ear for the past few months that isn't getting better. I also have some pain, itching, and ringing in that ear.

problem_summary.course: Persistent; did not subside with time or initial medical treatment (ear drops).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otalgia (ear pain), intermittent tinnitus, occasional itching.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Decreased hearing sensitivity in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation for why symptoms persisted despite previous treatment.

history.present_illness: Patient reports decreased hearing in the right ear for several months accompanied by otalgia. She previously saw a physician who diagnosed a right ear infection and prescribed drops, but symptoms did not resolve.
history.otologic_history: Right tympanic membrane perforation noted. Intermittent tinnitus and itching in the right ear.
history.prior_management: Prescribed ear drops by a physician for suspected infection; ineffective.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of persistent right ear symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear thresholds are within normal limits. Right ear shows a mild-to-moderate conductive hearing loss in the low frequencies, rising to mild in the mid-frequencies, and sloping to a moderate/moderately severe loss in the high frequencies. Bone conduction is normal bilaterally, indicating a conductive pathology in the right ear.

numeric_results.RE_AC_Thresholds: 40-45 dB HL (250-500 Hz), 35-40 dB HL (1000-4000 Hz), sloping to 60-70 dB HL at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) agree with pure-tone averages. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent/normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear tympanogram is normal (Type A). Right ear tympanogram is flat (Type B) with an abnormally large ear canal volume, consistent with a tympanic membrane perforation.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the left ear and a mild-to-moderately severe conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Word recognition remains excellent in the right ear when speech is loud enough. Tympanometry confirms a patent perforation in the right tympanic membrane (large ear canal volume). The findings are consistent with a middle ear pathology, later identified as cholesteatoma.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a 'conductive' hearing loss in the right ear, meaning sound is being blocked from reaching the inner nerve.
The pressure test (tympanometry) shows a large volume in the right ear canal, which confirms the presence of a hole (perforation) in the eardrum.
Because the ear drops did not help and there is a physical blockage/issue in the middle ear, this requires evaluation by an ENT specialist (otologist).
Keep the right ear dry (water precautions) until seen by the specialist to prevent infection.
notes_for_actor: Portray frustration that the previous doctor just gave you drops and they didn't work.
Mention that the right ear feels 'deeply' itchy sometimes, not just on the skin.
You are worried because the hearing loss hasn't gone away.
